title: History of Greek Culture. New York. An abridged English translation of this Swiss historian’s seminal work highlighting the competitive spirit among the ancient Greeks
The Mycenaean World. Cambridge. A standard reference work written by one of the scholars who deciphered Linear B
Manhood and Heroism
The Cambridge Companion to Homer. Cambridge. 74–90. A concise treatment of manhood and heroism in Homer’s poetry, including a discussion of how later Greeks viewed Homer’s heroes
The Oxford Handbook of the Bronze Age Aegean. Oxford. A collection of chapters on various topics pertaining to the Aegean Bronze Age, including warfare, trade, and cultural interaction

1177 B.C.: The Year Civilization Collapsed. Princeton. This book is essential reading for understanding the interconnected world of the Late Bronze Age and the collapse of major kingdoms throughout the eastern Mediterranean at the end of the thirteenth century bce

The End of the Bronze Age: Changes in Warfare and the Catastrophe ca. 1200 B.C. Princeton. A survey of Late Bronze Age warfare and an explanation of the Bronze Age collapse of kingdoms as due to the introduction of a new type of sword
The World of Odysseus. New York. This classic study treats the Homeric poems as providing insight into Early Iron Age and early Archaic Greek society rather than the Late Bronze Age

container-title: Demokratia: A Conversation on Democracies, Ancient and Modern. Princeton. 19–48. An important study about the development and nature of egalitarianism in the Greek polis
title: The Strong Principle of Equality and the Archaic Origins of Greek Democracy
The Fractured Imaginary: Popular Thinking on Military Matters in Fifth Century Athens
A good discussion of the place of the soldier in Athenian society, including the link between hoplites and citizens in iconography

War, Democracy and Culture in Classical Athens. Cambridge. A useful edited volume covering a wide range of topics on the interaction between war, politics, society, and culture in Classical Athens, including the relationship between hoplites and ideas of citizenship

note: In discussing the development of Greek pitched battle, Pritchett says dense phalanxes appear to be the norm already in the Iliad. The hoplite phalanx was thus more or less operative in Homer.
title: The Greek State at War
Arms and Armour of the Greeks. London. A groundbreaking study of the material remains of Greek arms and armor, with clear implications for the development of hoplite equipment and tactics
The Myth of the Middle-­Class Army: Military and Social Status in Ancient Athens
The Land of the Fine Triremes:” Naval Identity and Polis Imaginary in 5th Century Athens
This doctoral dissertation offers the most comprehensive study of naval imagery in Classical Athens, which, as Butera argues, was far more important to the city’s identity than is often recognized
Lords of the Sea: The Epic Story of the Athenian Navy and the Birth of Democracy. London. A gripping treatment of the navy and its role in expanding Athenian democracy

A War Like No Other: How the Athenians and Spartans Fought the Peloponnesian War. New York. An accessible introduction to the various military considerations in the study of the Peloponnesian War, including the importance of navies and sea-­power
The Corrupting Sea: A Study of Mediterranean History
A fascinating and wide-­ranging exploration of how the sea shaped the history of the Mediterranean region

The Defence of Greece, 490–479 B.C. Warminster. The best single-­volume study of the Persian Wars from a primarily military perspective. Essential reading for understanding the significance of the naval actions of Xerxes’ invasion

container-title: Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians
title: Framing Victory: Salamis, the Athenian Acropolis and the Agora

collection-title: Oxford. An up-­to-date collection of chapters on various aspects of Thucydidean scholarship
title: The Oxford Handbook of Thucydides
The New Politicians of Fifth-­Century Athens. Princeton. A seminal discussion of the changing nature of politics and political leaders before and during the Peloponnesian War
A Historical Commentary on Thucydides
The standard reference work for Thucydides as a historical source for the Peloponnesian War

A War Like No Other: How the Athenians and Spartans Fought the Peloponnesian War. New York. An engaging account of the various military considerations at play during the Peloponnesian War, and how the war fits into the context of ancient warfare more generally
A Commentary on Thucydides
Military Theory and Practice in the Age of Xenophon. Berkeley. Still an indispensable resource for understanding fourth-­century bce Greek warfare
Boiotia and the Boiotian League
A comprehensive treatment of Thebes and the Boiotian league, including Epameinondas and the Battle of Leuctra
Aegean Greece in the Fourth Century BC. Leiden. A leading historian provides a thorough account of the period covered by this chapter, including major military developments and campaigns

Agesilaos and the Crisis of Sparta. Baltimore. An invaluable account of the decline of Spartan prestige and military power in the fourth century bce, centered on the life and times of its most influential ruler
Dionysius I, War-­Lord of Sicily. New Haven. A useful book-­length treatment of Dionysius I of Syracuse and his historical context
Xenophon’s Anabasis or the Expedition of Cyrus. Oxford. A wide-­ranging yet accessible look at perhaps the most important literary source for early fourth-­century bce warfare

The Cambridge Companion to Xenophon. Cambridge. A recent collection of chapters on many aspects of Xenophon’s writing and his life and times. A important resource for understanding this fourth-­century bce source

The Mercenaries of the Hellenistic World. Groningen. Though focusing on the centuries following the period covered by this chapter, this is still an important work for understanding the phenomenon of mercenaries in general

Sparta’s Bitter Victories: Politics and Diplomacy in the Corinthian War. Ithaca. An important study of the Corinthian War of the first part of the fourth century bce, putting fourth-­century military developments in context

A Greek Army on the March: Soldiers and Survival in Xenophon’s “Anabasis.” Cambridge. A detailed study of the dynamics of the Greek mercenary army portrayed in Xenophon’s Anabasis, covering a range of issues pertinent to military history

Ancient Tyranny. Edinburgh. A collection of essays on ancient tyranny, including chapters on the fourth-­century bce rulers of Pherae, the tyrants of Sicily, and the connection between tyranny and military power in the fourth century bce
Greek and Roman Artillery: The Historical Development. Oxford. A comprehensive account of ancient artillery, which developed a great deal in the fourth century bce
Greek and Roman Artillery: Technical Treatises. Oxford. An exploration of the ancient technical manuals describing artillery and its use

note: This thesis has relevance for the sole rulers of the fourth century bce discussed in this chapter.
title: The Heroic Rulers of Archaic and Classical Greece. London. A readable exploration of sole rule in ancient Greece, arguing that sole rulers and tyrants never really went away, at least as a viable option to consider

note: The standard work on Greek mercenaries.
title: Greek Mercenary Soldiers, from the Earliest Times to the Battle of Ipsus

The Greek State at War, Part II. Berkeley. This volume contains an invaluable discussion of the so-­called condottieri of the fourth century bce. Pritchett concludes that the general impression of these generals being entirely independent from their states is overblown

note: and those Greeks (such as Xenophon and Iphicrates) who spent time in Thrace and led Thracian troops.
title: Athens, Thrace, and the Shaping of Athenian Leadership. Cambridge. This book includes a discussion of the innovations of fourth-­century bce Greek warfare, and the extent to which they were due to the influence of the Thracians, especially peltasts
A Historical Commentary on Diodorus Siculus, Book 15. Oxford. A vital commentary on one of the fourth century bce’s most important – if flawed –literary sources
The Generalship of Alexander the Great
A seasoned military commander himself, Fuller wrote one of the standard accounts of Alexander’s military genius

Alexander the Great Failure. London. This polemic argues that Alexander was in fact singularly unsuccessful, especially given his lack of strategic purpose and failure to secure a plan of succession for his sprawling empire
The Genius of Alexander the Great. Chapel Hill, NC. A representative introduction of Alexander as a singular genius, a notion that has come under increasing scrutiny in recent years

note: The definitive scholarly resource for ancient Macedonia.
title: A History of Macedonia
Who’s Who in the Age of Alexander the Great. London. A valuable resource that sorts out the immense and varied cast of characters connected to Alexander and his reign
Alexander the Great: Sources in Translation. Oxford. A convenient and scholarly collection of the major literary sources for Alexander

note: An excellent and comprehensive resource, with up-­to-date discussions and bibliography spanning the entire history of ancient Macedonia.
title: Into the Land of Bones: Alexander the Great in Afghanistan
Linking Alexander’s campaign to contemporary events, Holt provides a stirring account of the most difficult part of Alexander’s campaign in Asia. 180
Ancient Macedonia

The Persian Empire. London. A collection of texts and other sources illuminating the Persian Empire on its own terms, instead of the standard scholarly perspective that relies almost entirely on Greek sources

container-title: New Haven. Lendon argues that developments in Greek warfare, including the Macedonian phalanx of Philip II, were inspired by the desire to emulate the heroes of Homer’s Iliad
title: Soldiers and Ghosts: A History of Battle in Classical Antiquity
Greek and Roman Artillery: The Historical Development. Oxford. A comprehensive account of ancient artillery, which developed a great deal in the time of Philip and Alexander

Masters of Command: Alexander, Hannibal, Caesar, and the Genius of Leadership. New York. A comparison of three of antiquity’s most famous military leaders, with exciting, up-­ to-date discussions about Alexander’s tactics and strategy
Alexander the Great

note: Cambridge. An important collection of the scattered sources for the Hellenistic period, including much epigraphic evidence to supplement literary works.
title: The Hellenistic World from Alexander to the Roman Conquest: A Selection of Ancient Sources in Translation
War in the Hellenistic World: A Social and Cultural History
An exploration of the many themes pertinent to warfare beyond tactics and strategy, this book sheds a great deal of light on the Hellenistic world in general

Mediterranean Anarchy, Interstate War, and the Rise of Rome. Berkeley. This book focuses on the role of the Greco-­Macedonian powers of the eastern Mediterranean in spurring Roman imperialism and the eventual Roman conquest of the Hellenistic world

A Companion to the Roman Army. Oxford. An edited collection of chapters on the Roman army, including its development during the Republic and its clash with the Hellenistic kingdoms. 208 Warfare in the Hellenistic world
Philopoemen. Oxford. A standard resource for understanding the life and times of one of the Hellenistic world’s most important military leaders
Great Power Diplomacy in the Hellenistic World. London. A recent study on a vital but relatively under-­studied aspect of Hellenistic history, with obvious importance for military history

Alexander to Actium: The Historical Evolution of the Hellenistic Age. Berkeley. A sprawling and detailed narrative of 300 years of Hellenistic history. This book is very readable, but unfortunately neglects much of the scholarship and sources pertaining to the Near Eastern territories Alexander conquered
The Mercenaries of the Hellenistic World. Groningen. A standard reference work on Hellenistic mercenaries
The Hellenistic World and the Coming of Rome
Berkeley. Still an essential resource for understanding Greco-­Roman interactions during the Hellenistic period, including in the sphere of warfare

Hellenism in the East: The Interaction of Greek and Non-­Greek Civilizations from Syria to Central Asia after Alexander. London. A groundbreaking work focusing on the Near East on its own terms, drawing on Near Eastern sources from literature to archaeology, to illuminate the complex relationship between Greco-­Macedonians and native populations after Alexander

From Samarkhand to Sardis: A New Approach to the Seleucid Empire. Berkeley. Expanding on their earlier work, Kuhrt and Sherwin-­White provide a model for scholars seeking to move beyond Greco-­Roman sources in examining how Near Eastern peoples reacted and adapted to Greco-­Macedonians

Soldiers and Ghosts: A History of Battle in Classical Antiquity. New Haven. Provides a lively account of the Battle of Pydna between the Romans and Macedonians, including a useful overview of the Roman manipular legion that encountered the Macedonian phalanx
Fighting Poleis of the Hellenistic World

War and Violence in Ancient Greece. Swansea. 337–376. An important look at war at the micro-­level during the Hellenistic period. Even though most studies focus on great power politics, individual poleis continued to exercise agency and fought many wars with each other, and with and against the great powers

note: The standard work on Greek mercenaries.
title: Greek Mercenary Soldiers, from the Earliest Times to the Battle of Ipsus
The Roman Republican Army: A Sourcebook. London. A convenient, annotated collection of crucial sources for the Roman army that fought the Macedonian phalanx and the Hellenistic kingdoms

Masters of Command: Alexander, Hannibal, Caesar, and the Genius of Leadership. New York. In this comparison of three famous ancient commanders, Strauss provides an exciting account of Hannibal’s military career and situates him in the broader context of Greco-­ Roman warfare
A Historical Commentary on Polybius
A necessary resource for scholars using Polybius, one the Hellenistic period’s most important literary sources and one of the best ancient sources for warfare in general
Destined for War: Can America and China Escape Thucydides’s Trap?
Military Theory and Practice in the Age of Xenophon
Ashes, Images, and Memories: The Presence of the War Dead in Fifth-­Century Athens
The Hellenistic World from Alexander to the Roman Conquest: A Selection of Ancient Sources in Translation
The Oxford Handbook of Thucydides
Alone in the Village: Hesiod and his Community in the Works and Days
The Organisation of the Hittite Military
Hittite Diplomatic Texts
Thracian Peltasts and their Influence on Greek Warfare
Conquest and Empire: The Reign of Alexander the Great
The Kingdom of the Hittites

Thermopylae: The Battle that Changed the World
Dionysius I, War-­Lord of Sicily
